Why You Should Give Techno A Chance

By Orla McAndrew

Omar Amin (he/him) explains why everyone should give Techno a chance.

Immortal Longings: An Interview with New York Times bestselling author Chloe Gong

By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) interviews Chloe Gong about her debut adult fantasy novel Immortal Longings

Shopping: independent York boutiques

York's ethical boutique, One, on Grape Lane is a unique shopping experience of ethically sourced items...

The Mott Collection - "Loud Flash: British Punk on Paper"

The Haunch of Venison's current exhibition is an entertaining, raucous, brash, anarchic rampage through the rebellious era of the British Punk movement (Thumbnail credit TM0077. Chelsea, The Fall, The Snivelling Shits, Gig Poster, The Music Machine, London 1978)

Stomp

3pm. Ambassadors Theatre, Leicester Square. A surprisingly quaint and delicate little venue in light of the spectacle's reputation. On stage: caging, water butts, saucepans, drainpipes, stop signs, go signs, signs of a stomp-fest well in thumping order

Buried

There's only so much a film set entirely in a coffin can do, but <em>Buried</em> succeeds in just about doing it all

Eat Pray Love

As a reviewer, I feel obliged to point out that this film is... only alright. So-so. Watchable

The Town

<em>The Town</em> was bound to do well. Boasting a series of star names, a bombastic trailer and a big budget, this could have had no substance whatsoever and it would still rake in unjustified millions. What a relief, then, that it's a great film

The Other Guys

A cop movie whose cast boasts Mark Wahlberg, Michael Keaton, and Eva Mendes doesn't sound like the latest Will Ferrell/Adam McKay film; but maybe if you'd been in serious police dramas like The Corruptor, Desperate Measures and Training Day, then you'd be happy to jump onboard with the duo behind Anchorman and Talladega Nights to show audiences that you still had a sense of humour

The Runaways

Going into the cinema to see <em>The Runaways</em>, I couldn't help but feel ambivalent. On the one hand, it's a kinda-sorta-but-not-really biopic of Cherie Currie and Joan Jett, the two lead members of the titular band, and there's some defiantly feminist streak in me that means I get a kick out of seeing girls rocking out and telling the rest of the world where to stick it

Cyrus

The Duplass Brothers offer up a charming film that might easily have turned out a full-on gag-fest. Whilst it will consistently tickle you, the humour isn't belly-ache funny... but this is a good thing

Dinner for Schmucks

Remakes have a difficult time in the modern world of film, since they usually try and re-imagine a concept which is jealously guarded by the viewer, and they require walking a very fine tightrope to satisfy both the purists and the newcomers

22 Bullets

The main character of <em>22 Bullets</em> clearly never saw <em>The Godfather</em>, or at least he stopped watching it before the attempted assassination of Vito Corleone

Mother

Whilst South Korea's most internationally famous filmmaker in recent years has been <em>Oldboy</em> and <em>Lady Vengeance</em> revenge maestro Chan-wook Park, his contemporary Bong Joon-ho is starting to merit equal attention, as a director whose films also have their own set of recurring themes told with an idiosyncratic visual and dramatic style

Knight and Day

So, I confess, I am a Tom Cruise addict, and despite the wealth of criticism he receives, and despite his fall from box office grace, I still eagerly anticipate his films. So for me, <em>Knight and Day</em> was no exception, and it was an enjoyable, light-hearted popcorn film

Salt

Amongst the many effects of George W. Bush's presidency, a probably unimportant consequence has been overlooked: for much of the past decade, thrillers have been unable to include an American President as a character without implying to the audience that he's either greedy, over-powerful, stupid or evil

The Expendables

An interesting Belgian film called JCVD was released a couple of years ago. It's about an ageing action star - played by the actor himself - who is unwittingly caught up in a bank robbery, before being accused by police of being one of its perpetrators

The Secret in their Eyes

The winner of this year's Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film, The Secret in their Eyes feels very much like a classic genre film

Splice

When we think of scientific breakthroughs, we tend to credit a single person with the discovery or invention; that is, if our association goes at all beyond an anonymous group of scientists in a laboratory somewhere

Toy Story 3

"Whaaat? The Gypsy Kings version?" queries Chris Evans as the Spanish Octet's 'You've Got A Friend In Me' blares from his Radio 2 show. Well amigos, all becomes clear upon viewing Pixar's latest offering, the atomic bomb of action that is <em>Toy Story 3</em>

Best served chilled: The Big Chill 2010 review

When it comes to festivals I keep my expectations low. I fully expect to spend a weekend semi-homeless in an oversized plastic-bag coffin lacking any form of hygiene; a personal hell only transcended by the occasional live performance and temporary alcoholism. Hence discovering that The Big Chill offers every modern convenience was akin to a child from a deprived-upbringing being welcomed into a (really middle class) foster home

Anne Boleyn

Howard Brenton's exhilarant <em>Anne Boleyn</em> provides a refreshing addition to The Globe's potentially dry summer season, Kings & Rogues (Thumbnail credit Miranda Raison in Anne Boleyn by Howard Brenton. Photo credit: Manuel Harlan)

Charm//Offensive

Suitable for sketch show veterans or those (like myself) who are not attracted to the work of 'comedians', <em>Charm//Offensive</em> offers exactly what its edgy label presents (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Greg Bartlett)

Clubbed to Death

By James Bithell

Earlier this week York's dear Club Salvation, the pubescent hub of the University's nightlife, fell victim to what the hilarious scallywags of the Westboro Baptist Church might term a 'God Smack', as fire sent from the heavens enveloped its upper floors

Into-Flora

Jewellery curator Kath Libbert discusses her latest exhibition (Thumbnail credit Artist Natalya Pinchuk's work is all about growth: Number Two Growth. All images copyright Kath Libbert Gallery.)

1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces

It is said that 'interactive art' is for children. After a trip to the Victoria and Albert Museum's current exhibition 1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces, I can only beg to differ (Thumbnail credit 'Ark' by Rintala Eggertsson Architects)

A World Observed

A World Observed is the first major retrospective of London- based photographer Dorothy Bohm, now widely recognised as one of the doyennes of British photography (Thumbnail credit Lisbon, Portugal, 1963. Photograph by Dorothy Bohm)

That Face

Shocking is a completely inadequate word to use when describing Polly Stenham's two-act debut 'tragi-comedy' (Thumbnail credit Frances Barber as Martha)

Inception

There are not many films that manage to comprehensively warp reality with a sophistication and subtlety to rival that of The Matrix, but Inception may just be one of them

Staging an Intervention

Acclaimed artist Susan Stockwell talks to Beth Walton about sending art out into the public arena (Thumbnail credit Photography by Shannon Tofts)

Sean Scully: Works from the 1980s

Few things bug me more than bad grammar (Thumbnail credit Sean Scully, Without, 1988)

Alice Neel: Painted Truths

There is something almost frightening walking into the Whitechapel Gallery's new retrospective on Alice Neel
